document.docTitle: Oxyopomyrmex polybotesi Salata & Borowiec, 2015, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A taxonomic revision of the genus Oxyopomyrmex André, 1881 (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A taxonomic revision of the genus Oxyopomyrmex André, 1881 (Hymenoptera: Formicidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Oxyopomyrmex oculatus : Forel 1911 : 344
; Kiran & Karaman 2012 : 23 (misidentification) Etymology. Named after giant Polybotes. According to the Greek mythology, during the Gigantomachy Polybotes was crushed under Nisyros ( type locality of the species), which was thrown at him by Poseidon.
Type locality:
Moni Evangelistrias, Nisyros Is., Greece.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 58–60.
Oxyopomyrmex polybotesi
sp. nov.
[holotype] 58 , Worker dorsal (scale bar = 1 mm). 59 , Worker lateral (scale bar = 1 mm). 60 , Worker head (scale bar = 0.5 mm).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.
Holotype worker: GREECE , Dodecanese , 270 m | Nisyros, Moni Evangelistrias | 36,601 N / 27, 151 E |
1 VI 2001
, M. Chatzaki ( DBET )
;
45 paratype workers: the same data as holotype ( DBET , SSC )
.

Other material examined. 1 worker—
Oxyopomyrmex
|
oculatus Andre
? | Smyrne || Forel || Smyrne || MUSEUM PARIS | COLLECTION | ERNEST ANDRE | 1914 ( MNHN )
.

Biological data. Nothing is known about the biology of this species. In addition to the types , the following ant species were collected at the type locality:
Aphaenogaster sporadis Santschi
,
Aphaenogaster subterraneoides Emery
,
Cataglyphis nodus (Brullé)
,
Camponotus baldaccii Emery
,
Crematogaster ionia Forel
,
Lepisiota frauenfeldi (Mayr)
,
Messor wasmanni Krausse
,
Plagiolepis pygmea sensu Radchenko
,
Tetramorium cf. semilaeve
.

Differential diagnosis. Worker.
Oxyopomyrmex polybotesi
belongs to the species group that has a distinctly punctate propodeum. It is distinguished from
O. emeryi
and
O. oculatus
by the longitudinal striae covering whole frontal surface of the head and the presence of the rugosity and longitudinal striae on dorsal surface of the pronotum; from
O. negevensis
it differs in the lack of transverse striation on dorsal surface of the pronotum, the shiny abdomen and the more dense and thicker hairiness at the scape and legs. At first glance
O. polybotesi
is very similar to
O. pygmalioni
but it differs in following features: the shiny gena without rugosity (while
O. pygmalioni
has the gena dull and distinctly rugose), the occurrence of distinct longitudinal striae on the lateral surfaces of the pronotum (in
O. pygmalioni
the lateral surfaces of the pronotum are rugose with a slight longitudinal striae) and the dorsal surface of pronotum is shinier, weaker rugulose with longitudinal striae at the posterior edge (in
O. pygmalioni
the dorsal surface of pronotum is distinctly rugulose to rugose, and striation,if present, is oblique).
